data.name: Morpheus
data.shortDescription: Greek god of dreams, son of Hypnos (Sleep), who shapes and forms dreams.
data.longDescription: Morpheus is the Greek god of dreams and one of the Oneiroi (dream spirits). As the son of Hypnos and Pasithea, he possesses the unique ability to take any human form in dreams. Unlike his brothers Phobetor (nightmares) and Phantasos (surreal dreams), Morpheus specializes in delivering messages from the gods through accurate dream representations of humans.

data.name: Atalanta
data.shortDescription: Swift-footed huntress who refused marriage until defeated in a race.
data.longDescription: Atalanta was a renowned Greek heroine, raised by bears and known for her incredible speed and hunting prowess. She participated in the Calydonian Boar Hunt and was the first to wound the beast. She vowed to remain unmarried unless a suitor could defeat her in a footrace, with death as the penalty for losing.

data.name: Phoenix
data.shortDescription: Immortal bird that cyclically regenerates through fire.
data.longDescription: The Phoenix is a mythical bird that obtains new life by arising from the ashes of its predecessor. It lives for 500 years before building a nest of aromatic wood and spices, which it then sets ablaze. From the ashes, a young phoenix emerges, renewed and reborn.

rejectionReason: Please add more detail about the Phoenix's symbolism and provide scholarly sources. The description is too brief for publication.

data.name: Mj√∂lnir
data.shortDescription: Thor's mighty hammer, capable of leveling mountains and returning to his hand.
data.longDescription: Mj√∂lnir is the enchanted hammer wielded by Thor, forged by the dwarven brothers Brokkr and Eitri. It is one of the most formidable weapons in Norse mythology, capable of destroying mountains and slaying giants. The hammer always returns to Thor's hand after being thrown and can only be lifted by those deemed worthy.

data.name: Mount Kailash
data.shortDescription: Sacred mountain in Tibet, considered the abode of Lord Shiva.
data.longDescription: Mount Kailash is a 6,638-meter peak in the Kailash Range of the Transhimalaya in Tibet. It holds immense religious significance in Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, and Bon. In Hindu tradition, it is believed to be the abode of Lord Shiva and his consort Parvati. Buddhists consider it the home of Buddha Cakrasa·πÉvara.

data.name: Dharma
data.shortDescription: Cosmic law and order; righteous duty in Hinduism and Buddhism.
data.longDescription: Dharma is a key concept in Indian religions encompassing duties, rights, laws, conduct, virtues, and the right way of living. In Hinduism, it represents the cosmic law underlying right behavior and social order. In Buddhism, it refers to the teachings of the Buddha and the path to enlightenment.

data.name: Sei√∞r
data.shortDescription: Norse magical practice involving prophecy, shapeshifting, and spirit work.
data.longDescription: Sei√∞r is a type of Norse magic associated with prophecy and altering the course of destiny. Practiced primarily by women called v√∂lvas, it involved trance states, spirit journeys, and communication with the divine. The practice was considered somewhat shameful for men, though Odin himself was said to have learned it from Freyja.

data.title: Universal Flood Myths and Climate Events
data.shortDescription: Analysis of flood narratives across cultures and potential historical climate events.
data.content:
## Overview

Flood myths appear in numerous unrelated cultures worldwide, from the Biblical Noah to the Mesopotamian Utnapishtim, Hindu Manu, and Greek Deucalion. This theory examines potential connections to actual catastrophic flooding events.

## Key Points

1. **Cultural Distribution**: Flood myths span at least 50 cultures across 6 continents
2. **Common Elements**: Divine warning, chosen survivors, animals saved, divine covenant
3. **Geological Evidence**: End of last ice age caused significant sea level rise

## Analysis

The prevalence of flood myths may reflect:
- Actual regional flooding events preserved in oral tradition
- Rising sea levels (120m) at end of last glaciation (~11,700 years ago)
- Universal human experience with devastating floods

## Connections

- Epic of Gilgamesh (c. 2100 BCE)
- Genesis flood narrative (c. 1450 BCE)
- Greek Deucalion myth
- Hindu Matsya Purana
- Chinese Great Flood legends

entityName: Universal Flood Myths and Climate Events

data.name: Bastet
data.shortDescription: Egyptian goddess of home, fertility, and cats; protector against evil spirits.
data.longDescription: Bastet is the Egyptian goddess of home, fertility, and childbirth. Originally depicted as a fierce lioness warrior, she evolved into the familiar cat-headed goddess associated with domesticity and protection. She was the daughter of Ra and played a protective role against evil spirits and disease.

data.name: Yoruba Mythology
data.shortDescription: Rich spiritual tradition of the Yoruba people featuring the Orishas.
data.longDescription: Yoruba mythology is the spiritual and religious system of the Yoruba people of Nigeria, Benin, and Togo. It centers on the Orishas (divine spirits) and their relationship with humans. The supreme deity Olodumare created the universe, while Orishas like Oshun, Shango, and Yemoja govern specific aspects of life and nature.
